| eV/c 2 inunits2 = units3 = m e inunits3 = 1822.88839

}} The 'unified atomic mass unit' (symbol: 'u') or 'dalton' (symbol: 'Da') is
the standard unit that is used for indicating mass on an atomic or molecular
scale (atomic mass). It is defined as one twelfth of the mass of an unbound
neutral atom of carbon-12 in its nuclear and electronic ground state, and has a value of . [http://physics.nist.gov/constants Fundamental Physical Constants
from NIST ] One dalton is approximately equal
to the mass of one nucleon and equivalent to 1g/mol. The CIPM has categorised it as a non-SI unit accepted for use with
the SI, and whose value in SI units must be obtained experimentally.

The 'amu' without the "unified" prefix is technically an obsolete unit based on
oxygen, which was replaced in 1961. However, some sources still use the amu but
now define it in the same way as u (based on carbon-12). In this sense, most
uses of atomic mass units or amu today actually refer to unified atomic mass
units or u.

Atomic mass unit does not stand for the unit of mass in the atomic units system,
which is rather m e.
